paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, and can JWST phase-curve plus spectral data distinguish atmosphere-bearing from bare-rock scenarios?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b phase-curve dataset
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One rocky exoplanet observed with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy across orbital phase was used to measure thermal phase variation and spectral structure near 15 um.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A no-atmosphere, minimal-redistribution case representing the bare-rock limit was used as a null model against atmospheric retrievals.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-bearing retrieval models with significant greenhouse absorption were evaluated, including constraints from the 15 um CO2 region.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized-composition atmospheric branch with weaker CO2 signature constraints was considered and not fully excluded by the current data.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish prevalence across rocky M-dwarf planets.
Retrieval assumptions such as circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect posterior estimates.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
